title: 1260 Index

Page 1281

1260 Index

Quicksort

Pick a pivot, put smaller left, larger right, repeat

Choose one person as the 'pivot'. Everyone shorter goes left, everyone taller goes right. Now repeat for each group.

How It Works

  1. Pick a pivot element (often last element)
  2. Partition: move smaller elements left, larger right
  3. Pivot is now in its final position
  4. Recursively sort left and right partitions

Complexity

  • Time Best: O(n log n)
  • Time Avg: O(n log n)
  • Time Worst: O(nÂ²) - rare with good pivot
  • Space: O(log n) - recursion stack

When to Use

  • General-purpose sorting
  • Average case matters most
  • In-place sorting needed
  • Cache efficiency important

Depth-First Search

Go as deep as possible, then backtrack

Exploring a maze by always taking the first path until you hit a dead end, then backtracking.

How It Works

  1. Start at source, mark as visited
  2. For each unvisited neighbor:
  3. - Recursively DFS from that neighbor
  4. When all neighbors done, backtrack

Complexity

  • Time: O(V + E)
  • Space: O(V) for recursion stack

When to Use

  • Detecting cycles
  • Topological sorting
  • Finding strongly connected components
  • Maze solving
  • Pathfinding (not shortest)
